climbs.name: Diurnal pegs
climbs.fa: Fa: Colin Bell, G.Lacroix FFA: John Bowles, Brent Cruickshank

content.description:
Diurnal pegs start just right of the great roof and follows discontinuous cracks to a bolted anchor. This route R rating is because of the run out to the first pin about 12-15 up.

Diurnal pegs was developed in 1977 by Colin Bell and G.Lacroix and was original an aid line that was given the aid grade of A1. Diurnal Pegs was the first climb in New Brunswick to have a bolt placed on it, the bolt was placed about 5 feet from the ground but was removed around 2010. In 2004 local hard men John Bowles and Brent Cruickshank freed the original line with a starting variation and gave the route a grade of 5.11 R.


Right of the great roof
Bring a rack, There are 2 older pins placed on the climb that may need replacing.

climbs.name: The Great Roof
climbs.fa: C.Bell and G.LaCroix  (1978) FFA - Steve Adamson (1993)

content.description:
This is the short finger roof crack on the left side of the great roof. This crack eats cams and pulling the lip is tricky for aid climbing. There is still a fixed pin at the lip. After the lip the climbing get easier and most people can free climb to the top with the use of the trees. Make for a great first aid climb.  
  
 When Steve Adamson climbed this route free in 1993, he redubbed it "Go ahead make my Day" but the name never caught on...

Left side of the great roof.
standard rack, Leave the Hammer Home.

climbs.name: Hatful of Hollow
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Mike Parker and Mike Delaney

content.description:
The gear is a little wonky on this.  Nuts work well.  The middle section moving into the steepness is not great but the last 20 feet makes up for it.  The moves after the pin are fun, fun.

Start on the same ledge as The Reach Around but move straight up to a corner with a crack in it.  Climb the corner to a narrow ledge. Clip a pin then continue to the top.  Move up on 3rd class terrain to and anchor off a tree.  Rap the route or move right and rap The Silver Sword.
Single rack to 3".  One piton protects the final moves to the top out.

climbs.name: Knuckle Sandwich
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Mike Parker and Mike Delaney

content.description:
Face holds lead to a corner with a finger crack.  Climb the corner to the top of a ledge, step up onto the ledge and ascend a steep headwall to the top.  Super fun climbing, steep, juggy with thoughful movement but beware the corner crack has been known to hold onto to fingers.

Up the slope from the Great Roof.  Start five feet right of Hatfull of Hollow. Rap the route or step right and rap The Silver Sword.
Single rack to 1".  Tree anchor.

climbs.name: Oggie Oggie
climbs.fa: ffa: Ian Lingley, Josh Shewbridge  fa: Colin Bell 1978

content.description:
This was originally an aid route put up in the late 70's and forgotten about.  
 The route starts left of the great route at a steep crack that you use to pull the lip of the roof. After the cruxy start you continue up and right through a series of cracks.   
 It would be possible to traverse from the left and bypass the starting crux.

Just left of the great roof,
Standard rack

climbs.name: The Reach Around
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Mike Parker and Josh Shewbridge

content.description:
After an easy but steep start move up and left on good holds to a series of sloping ledges and a slab. Head up the slab to a thin crack where the wall steepens. Move up to gain a ledge and then traverse left through overhanging terrain on nice jugs all the way to the top corner of the wall. A semi blind reach up and left unlocks the crux sequence. 

Up and right of the Great Roof 20 feet above the start of Diurnal Pegs. After topping out move up and right on 3rd class terrain to a tree anchor.  After belaying the second up move 30 feet right and rappell The Silver Sword.
Single rack to 2". A purple tcu protects the traverse across the ledge. There is a run out up to the slab but the climbing is not that difficult.

Climb the crack to the vegetated ledge.  Continue to the obvious corner above.  Climb the fun corner to a tree anchor.

The last route on the right side of the wall. Just right of Knuckle Sandwich. Start up easy face climbing to a wide crack that trends right.
Single rack to 4".  Tree anchor.

This route is quite overgrown and not very clean.  It is still climbable but you should be ready for some dirt.  The top half is not bad as it has had some work done to it.

About 15 feet right of the big corner where Yin and Yang are located.  See photo.  Rap the route.
Standard rack to 3".  Tree anchor.

Uber classic line. Great movement on excellent rock. History: This route was put up in 1976 by Tom Butz and the original grade was 5.1. It has been adjusted to reflect current grading practices. This is also the oldest recorded rock climb in New Brunswick.



Located about in the middle of the slab between the Great Roof and Yin/Yang corner. Look for three big blocks stacked on top of each other. Climb up the blocks then move up to a large elephant head shaped feature. Continue up to a tree ledge. Step right then up to gain a small arete. Follow the left side of the arete until you reach a fist crack that narrows down to hands near the top of the route.


Standard rack to 3". Bolted anchor

The True Great Roof is the thin pin seam that splits through the center of the great roof. This line starts on some iffy gear but at the base of the roof there are a few small cam placements, after that is piton seam (surprising deep) out and around the lip. The top out can be a little tricky if there is ice and snow covering the placement over the lip. But there are a few cracks and some med cam placements once above the lip.

Center of the Great roof
Standard rack, Pins, hammer maybe a pecker.. use your imagination bring every thing.

This is a very pleasant crack climb with a nice variety of finger and hand jams from top to bottom. The original grade from 1977 was 5.1! It has been adjusted to reflect current grades.


Start is just right of Tom's Route. Traverse right across a ledge about 10 feet and then head up the discontinuous vertical cracks.

Stand rack to 3". Bolted anchor.

The area is shaped like an amphitheater with the Great roof on the far right and the wall ending on the left near Powder Greens. There is little room for development in this area due to the shape of the rock and the abundance of ledges breaking the cliff up.
